title: 103_s479
content: The "Small Business Incentive Act of 1993" amends the Securities Act of 1933 to increase the exemption threshold from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000 and excludes certain securities from the definition of an investment company. Section 3(c) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to deem certain issuers as investment companies for specific purposes outlined in section 12(d)(1). The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies for specific purposes related to ownership of securities by qualified purchasers. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies for specific purposes related to ownership of securities by qualified purchasers. SEC. 4 defines a qualified purchaser. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to define a "qualified purchaser" as a natural person owning at least $10,000,000 in securities or a person owning and investing at least $100,000,000 in securities on a discretionary basis. The Commission may determine that certain individuals with a higher level of financial sophistication, substantial net worth, significant assets, relationships with issuers, or other relevant factors do not require the protections of the Investment Company Act of 1940. The Commission has the authority to establish rules and regulations regarding this determination. The Commission has the authority to adopt rules and regulations for specified individuals in the public interest and for investor protection. SEC. 5 amends the definition of investment securities in the Investment Company Act of 1940. SEC. 6 provides an exemption for economic, business, and industrial development companies. Section 6(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include a new paragraph stating that companies not issuing redeemable securities and regulated by the state can provide financial or managerial assistance for economic development within the state. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow companies in a state to engage in business activities and sell securities to accredited investors or persons with a substantial business presence in that state. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment allows companies to sell securities to accredited investors or persons with a substantial business presence in a state, as permitted by the Commission. The company is restricted from purchasing securities issued by investment companies, except for certain exclusions like investment-grade securities or those issued by registered open-end investment companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment allows companies to invest at least 65 percent of their assets in specific securities or comparable quality securities. Companies relying on this exemption must comply with certain provisions and file with the Commission. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment allows companies to invest at least 65 percent of their assets in specific securities or comparable quality securities. Companies must file a notification with the Commission to rely on the exemption provided by this paragraph, subject to additional terms and conditions determined by the Commission. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment increases the closed-end investment company exemption from $100,000 to $10,000,000 or as determined by the Commission. Additionally, the definition of eligible portfolio company is clarified. SEC. 8 amends the definition of eligible portfolio company under the Investment Company Act of 1940, specifying criteria related to total assets and capital. SEC. 9 addresses the definition of a business development company. SEC. 9 amends the definition of a business development company under the Investment Company Act of 1940, allowing exceptions for providing managerial assistance to certain types of companies. SEC. 10 pertains to the acquisition of assets by business development companies. SEC. 10 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 to allow business development companies to acquire assets from any person, subject to SEC regulations. Section 61(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change the asset coverage requirements for business development companies. The new requirements state that the asset coverage shall be 200 percent, but a company may have a coverage of not less than 110 percent under certain conditions. The new requirements for business development companies under the Investment Company Act of 1940 state that the asset coverage shall be 200 percent, with specific conditions allowing for coverage of not less than 110 percent. It is unlawful for any business development company to issue senior securities representing a certain percentage of its assets invested in specific securities. The company must ensure that any class of senior security issued has an asset coverage of at least 110 percent after deducting dividends, distributions, or purchase prices. The business development company must comply with certain requirements to maintain its status as a regulated investment company under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It is unlawful for the company to issue senior securities representing stock without provisions to restrict dividends or distributions on common stock, or the purchase of common stock. The business development company must have asset coverage of at least 110 percent after deducting dividends, distributions, or purchase prices. It must also comply with requirements to maintain regulated investment company status under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. In paragraph (3), a business development company may issue warrants, options, or rights to subscribe to voting securities not accompanied by indebtedness. A business development company can issue warrants, options, or rights to subscribe to voting securities if authorized by shareholders or partners and approved by the required majority of directors or general partners. SEC. 12. FILING OF WRITTEN STATEMENTS. Amendment to the Investment Company Act of 1940 to include "and capital structure" after "portfolio".
